content.description:
Below the Massie boulder you will see this slab section of the Wilburn Waters Boulder sticking up from the Rhodos. 

  Walk down the little pony path to the boulder and this slab will be the first face you see. Stand start near the far right corner section and scale the fun, easy slab to the top. Stay to the far right.
When at the slab wall, this on starts 3-4ft to the right of the left-most edge of the slab face. Work direct up through a few long pockets in the face to the top.

Low start on a dirty series of sidepulls. Leads to a balance move, more dirty sidepulls, and a juggy topout. 

  Chocked stone near topout won't get knocked off, but is untested as a hold. You don't need it.
content.location: On the opposite side of the Wilburn Waters Boulder from the slabs, climber's right of the downclimb.

content.description:
Massive... Even the slab on this one is heady. 

  This boulder is awesome and worth checking out, especially if you have a pension for getting some serious distance between you and the ground.  

  The side you first come to has some fun, easy slabs that are likewise on the tall and exciting side. 

  The Wilburn Waters Boulder is named after the famed hunter-trapper of the region named Wilburn Waters. He hunted bear and wolf in the highlands in the 1800's and his adventures are well beyond belief. The Wilburn Ridge is named in his honor as well. A book that retails some of his more notable adventures is sold in the office and visitors center and its worth a look. He went hand to hand with black bears and wolves on multiple occasions This type of determination might help you get to the top of this highball.
